children.name: p
children: Below are instructions on how to set up a basic Manifest Player which is a player that uses a manifest URL to receive video data.

children.name: p
children: video consumer API. It allows a user to receive video and audio data via a web call. The Player API is intended for unidirectional video streaming applications such as one-way education, presentation, performance, and more.

children.name: p
children: 's Player API can either be used as a standalone JavaScript API or as a React Component Library. The instructions below outline how to create a simple Manifest Player application using React.

children.name: p
children: npm packages, which means they will be included in the bundle and the player will be ready to play stream without additional requests. It's possible to exclude it from the bundle and load it on demand, which decreases the bundle size but adds a small delay before
start playing. To do that you need some js minifier with the ability to replace
with literals and remove dead code from the bundle and pass

children.name: p
children: The Player is 's video consumer API. There are two different kinds of players, Web Conference players and Manifest players. A
is used when connecting to a known
It allows a user to receive video and audio data via a web call. In this guide we will be learning how to create a Manifest Player using Vanilla JavaScript.

children.name: p
children: 's Player API can either be used as a standalone JavaScript API or as a React Component Library.
The instructions below outline how to create a simple Manifest Player application using Vanilla JavaScript.

children.name: p
children: Below are step-by-step instructions on how to set up a Manifest Player using Vanilla JavaScript.
If you want to just skip to the end and see it all put together, head

children.name: p
children: dependency inside of a Vanilla JavaScript application you must use a static module bundler. For this example we will be using webpack.

children.name: pre
h3
children: Step 2: Now create your HTML page for your Player and add the created bundle

children.name: p
children: instance takes as a parameter an

children.name: li
children: - An array of loadbalancer urls. These are optional when using a manifest player, for a web conference player this is required, so for this example it will be required.

children.name: li
children: - The id for the stream that is being viewed.

children.name: li
children: - A boolean that determines if players should autoplay (

children: - Passing this option appends the preferred app name to Video Client logs, i.e. "videoclient:loggerClientName"

children.name: p
children: class is the foundation of the Video web encoder and player. It provides access
to a Call as well as manages peer state. For this function we are going to want to receive a manifest URL which will be required for the

children.name: pre
children:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <body>
    <script src="/videoClientLib.js"></script>
    <script>
      function createVideoClient() {
        //Here we are grabbing the streamKey at the end of our manifestURL
        const streamKey = manifestUrl.slice(
          manifestUrl.lastIndexOf("/") + 1,
          manifestUrl.indexOf(".json")
        );
        //Creating our VideoClient instance
        const vc = new VideoClient.VideoClient({
          backendEndpoints: ["https://yourEndpoint"],
          stats: {
            app: "Storybook",
            userId: uuid,
            statsInterval: 5000,
            streamId: streamKey,
            studioId: "321",
          },
        });
        return false;
      }
    </script>
  </body>
</html>

children.name: h3
children: Step 5: Create our player using the VideoClient

children.name: p
children: Next we need to create our
, this can be done by requesting a new player from the

children.name: pre
children:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <body>
    <script src="/videoClientLib.js"></script>
    <script>
      function createVideoClient() {
        //Here we are grabbing the streamKey at the end of our manifestURL
        const streamKey = manifestUrl.slice(
          manifestUrl.lastIndexOf("/") + 1,
          manifestUrl.indexOf(".json")
        );

        const vc = new VideoClient.VideoClient({
          backendEndpoints: ["https://yourEndpoint"],
          stats: {
            app: "Storybook",
            userId: uuid,
            statsInterval: 5000,
            streamId: streamKey,
            studioId: "321",
          },
        });
        let player;
        try {
          //Here we are creating our player from the VideoClient
          player = vc.requestPlayer(manifestUrl);
        } catch (err) {
          throw err;
        }

        return false;
      }
    </script>
  </body>
</html>

children.name: h3
children: Step 6: Add our player to the page

children.name: p
children: Now we need to create a method that will add our player to our web page.

children.name: pre
h3
children: Step 8: Add an input for the manifest URL

children.name: p
children: Finally we are going to add an input where a manifest URL can be added and sent to our created function. Note: this is not the required way to do this, likely you will want to add the manifestUrl without user input but this is a good way to test if your player is working as expected with different manifests.
